eventName: Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divide
description:
November 30, 2024 - February 23, 2025Curated by Karly BoileauWith a focus on a slow-making process through a Japanese heritage craft practice, Hitoko Okada’s major solo exhibition explores new ceramic and textile works that critically engage with and question the global fashion supply chain as it relates to colonial histories of fast fashion. Her works draw inspiration from geological processes and metabolic evolution of fungi, to apply ancestral knowledge in a present-day context to re-imagine futurisms and ways of being through a queer lens.Explore Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divideAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. September 12, 2024 - January 17, 2025Visit the lobby at Idea Exchange Queen's Square to experience an installation featuring a vibrant collection of items draping the doorway. The installation encourages a moment of pause to wonder and search as the work inspires critiques of consumerism. Torres’ installation uses familiar domestic, institutional, and recreational items to elevate our appreciation of the everyday while also inviting reflection on the challenges of consumer culture—our tendency to accumulate and the growing complexities of storing, recycling, and disposing of surplus goods.This installation reuses the items from Material Culture, an exhibition produced by the University of Waterloo Art Gallery. They generously allowed us to give the items another life before donating them to consumer distribution.Explore: José Luis Torres: A Site-Specific InstallationAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

description:
As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. location.name: Queen's Square - Children's Program Room IdeaExchange

description:
View an award-winning cinematic feature film presented by the NFB.Directed by Monique LeBlanc2023 | 75 min Documentary Original EnglishThe Geographies of DAR is a captivating film that explores the life and literary works of renowned Canadian author David Adams Richards.Through stunning visuals, insightful interviews and excerpts from his writings, the film uncovers the profound connection between Richards’ personal experiences and Eastern Canada’s Miramichi, the region that shaped his storytelling.The masterful cinematography showcases the harsh yet beautiful landscapes of Richards’ Miramichi, taking viewers on a journey through the complex lives of his characters, marked by destruction, freedom and redemption.Richards opens up about his childhood, his struggles and demons, and his unwavering belief in God, providing candid and perceptive insights into cruelty, love, faith and the human experience.This poignant film is an elegy to the joys, suffering, mercies and beauty of life, celebrating the indomitable spirit and courage of this extraordinary Canadian writer.This program is offered as part of the NFB in Libraries program. The film was generously provided for this event by the National Film Board of Canada (NFB).We encourage you to register for this event. However, limited seating may be available at the door on a first-come, first-served basis.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. location.name: Clemens Mill - Creative Hub Classroom IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

September 12, 2024 - January 17, 2025Visit the lobby at Idea Exchange Queen's Square to experience an installation featuring a vibrant collection of items draping the doorway. The installation encourages a moment of pause to wonder and search as the work inspires critiques of consumerism. Torres’ installation uses familiar domestic, institutional, and recreational items to elevate our appreciation of the everyday while also inviting reflection on the challenges of consumer culture—our tendency to accumulate and the growing complexities of storing, recycling, and disposing of surplus goods.This installation reuses the items from Material Culture, an exhibition produced by the University of Waterloo Art Gallery. They generously allowed us to give the items another life before donating them to consumer distribution.Explore: José Luis Torres: A Site-Specific InstallationAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

description:
As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. eventName: Cookies and Kids Performing Arts Series: Tribal Vision Dance
description: Explore First Nations history and traditions in Tribal Vision’s high-energy performance! The artist will explain the history and significance of their dances and illustrate the cultural experience of First Nations peoples in Canada. This show is an introduction to the powwow culture of North American Indigenous people. Join the artists for an interactive session and learn more about First Nations regalia, dances, and First Nations history.Performace is suitable for families of all ages.Register online through Cambridge.ca/coral.   Activity Code:  564018.   Or visit a Cambridge Recreation Centre for your tickets.

description:
Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

location.name: Old Post Office - Creative Studios IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

location.name: Old Post Office - Reading Room IdeaExchange

description:
Rebuilding connections through collective care: TEAO Canada's trauma-informed circles blend somatic practices, psycho-education, and breathwork for healing.Group processing may be an area deserving of more time in communities, organically through conversations, breathwork and movement, which is how Trauma Informed Care Circle (TEAO) has begun to address trauma care and trauma health in communities.These circles will incorporate psycho-education, somatic health, and breathwork to get participants in their somatic bodies to begin to process trauma. We are coming together in somatic movement during the group processing circle so that debriefing, trauma care, and systemic care can be processed.About our PartnerTEAO Canada will hold space for participants, led by Nicole Brown Faulknor — as both a trauma consultant/facilitator and registered psychotherapist. Nicole will explore somatic practices as well, as a way to support rebuilding a relationship with our bodies through collective grief, workspace conflict, and institutional helplessness as a place to be heard (loved) in/from places of systems and hierarchical powerlessness and why your emotional health is our mental health.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. November 30, 2024 - February 23, 2025Curated by Karly BoileauWith a focus on a slow-making process through a Japanese heritage craft practice, Hitoko Okada’s major solo exhibition explores new ceramic and textile works that critically engage with and question the global fashion supply chain as it relates to colonial histories of fast fashion. Her works draw inspiration from geological processes and metabolic evolution of fungi, to apply ancestral knowledge in a present-day context to re-imagine futurisms and ways of being through a queer lens.Explore Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divideAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

eventName: Connections 50+ Presents Cambridge Third Age Learning
description:
The founders of the museum will talk about how the Fashion History Museum came to be in Cambridge, including images of items in the collection, and information about current and upcoming shows.Cambridge was at the heart of the textile and clothing production industries in Canada in the 19th Century. Established in Cambridge with an international presence, Fashion History Museum (FHM) chronicles the necessity and cultural expression of clothing, has mounted shows at the Museum in the old Hespeler Post Office, and at the Regional Museum, drawing up to 24,000 visitors per show. Major Museums across the world have been mounting fashion exhibitions more frequently in the past two decades, with greater and greater success and popularity.FHM will have their book, Our First Twenty Years, for sale or purchases can be made on their website.About Cambridge Third Age LearningCambridge Third Age Learning (CTAL) is a movement that encourages learning and discovery experiences for those in the 'third age'. As part of our Connections 50+ suite of programming, CTAL provides free monthly lectures in our Queen's Square location. With lecturers and topics carefully selected by our CTAL Committee, a volunteer-led group of contemporaries, the series is designed to inspire new thinking and engage inquisitive minds.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. GUNG HAGGIS FAT CHOY!Join the FRIENDS of Waterloo Region Museums for a fundraising event-- A celebration fusion of both the Chinese New Year and Scottish Robbie Burns Day, that offers performers and food tastings of each culture. This event is fashioned from a successful Gung Haggis Fat Choy in Vancouver. The name is Cantonese for “We wish you to be rich”!Performers will include the fun and entertaining Scantily Plaid, the amazing Grand River Chinese Orchestra, and other talented special guests! Bagpipes, lion dancers, highland dancing, and more!Refreshments include food and soft drink samplings from each culture.Register Now

Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. location.name: Old Post Office - Reading Room IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. description:
November 30, 2024 - February 23, 2025Curated by Karly BoileauWith a focus on a slow-making process through a Japanese heritage craft practice, Hitoko Okada’s major solo exhibition explores new ceramic and textile works that critically engage with and question the global fashion supply chain as it relates to colonial histories of fast fashion. Her works draw inspiration from geological processes and metabolic evolution of fungi, to apply ancestral knowledge in a present-day context to re-imagine futurisms and ways of being through a queer lens.Explore Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divideAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

location.name: Old Post Office - Reading Room IdeaExchange

description:
Rebuilding connections through collective care: TEAO Canada's trauma-informed circles blend somatic practices, psycho-education, and breathwork for healing.Group processing may be an area deserving of more time in communities, organically through conversations, breathwork and movement, which is how Trauma Informed Care Circle (TEAO) has begun to address trauma care and trauma health in communities.These circles will incorporate psycho-education, somatic health, and breathwork to get participants in their somatic bodies to begin to process trauma. We are coming together in somatic movement during the group processing circle so that debriefing, trauma care, and systemic care can be processed.About our PartnerTEAO Canada will hold space for participants, led by Nicole Brown Faulknor — as both a trauma consultant/facilitator and registered psychotherapist. Nicole will explore somatic practices as well, as a way to support rebuilding a relationship with our bodies through collective grief, workspace conflict, and institutional helplessness as a place to be heard (loved) in/from places of systems and hierarchical powerlessness and why your emotional health is our mental health.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

description: McDougall Cottage’s mouth-watering “Death by Chocolate” Tea by the Grand makes its return, just in time for Valentine’s Day!Grab a special someone, or two, and head down to McDougall Cottage for an indulgent tea experience featuring one of the most beloved flavours of all time, chocolate.We’ll be serving decadent chocolate treats and drinks, alongside a couple of McDougall's ever-popular tea classics, like cucumber and cream-cheese sandwiches, and bottomless tea, of course.If you and your valentine or pal-entine have a sweet tooth, this event is for you!Reserve your spot today—because when it comes to chocolate, too much is never enough!Note: Tickets are also available for in-person purchase at the Cottage during McDougall Cottage's hours of operation.Register NowPlease note:Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum members receive a 10% discount.Tickets are non-refundable.

Join us at Schneider Haus February 8th and 9th for our Valentine's day crafternoons! Enjoy crafts like paper heart ornament making, custom valentines cards with heart confetti, and join us in decorating Schneider Haus' favourite cookies, Sandhearts! Nothing is sweeter than a hand decorated cookie. These activities are included in the price of admission and take place during our open hours from 11 am to 4 pm.

eventName: Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divide
description:
November 30, 2024 - February 23, 2025Curated by Karly BoileauWith a focus on a slow-making process through a Japanese heritage craft practice, Hitoko Okada’s major solo exhibition explores new ceramic and textile works that critically engage with and question the global fashion supply chain as it relates to colonial histories of fast fashion. Her works draw inspiration from geological processes and metabolic evolution of fungi, to apply ancestral knowledge in a present-day context to re-imagine futurisms and ways of being through a queer lens.Explore Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divideAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

eventName: What the Health!? A Health Information Fair
description: Explore community health resources for everyone. Get your blood pressure checked. Learn about support groups, recreational opportunities, and special programs for people of all ages. Visit the exhibit Beyond the Bricks: 100 Years of Compassionate Care at St. Mary's General Hospital.

Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized.
